body: Can you tell us the amount of tests executed in that suite?

It is ~2,650 testcases, across about 200 test classes.  Most are very fast-running, small/lightweight/low memory tests.  Just a handful of them use a lot more memory and run for several seconds.

The suite takes about 3 minutes to run when using gradle to run it across 4 JVM processes in parallel.  So really those numbers are sort of divided by 4 in the process that actually hits OutOfMemoryError.  (In my upcoming experiment to pare down the list to try to narrow down the problem, I'll be turning off parallel runs to help unmuddy the waters.)

I should also have mentioned that we are running everything using Java 8.  And I reproduced the same issue on both Linux and Windows.

Also notable: we have 20 subprojects, each with 1000's of tests, and only two of our subprojects hit this issue.  The info I already provided was all from just one of those problematic subprojects, which I selected to work with to try to root cause the issue (because it is the fastest-running).

If paring down does not reveal the source (it may just be higher overall memory consumption of JUnit 5 due to some implementation detail), it may be helpful to run the suite with 5.2 and 5.3 and create a heap dump during peak memory consumption. An inspection might show what kind of objects make up the addition GBs. That may end up being a lot of work, though.

That's a great idea.  I'm experienced with Java heap analysis and memory leak debugging already, so I know how to do that.  I think this experiment is somewhat likely to clarify whether this is really a Junit 5.3 issue, or an issue with our tests.  I'll report back here when I have more clues.

What I see in my heap dump is that there are tons of test class instances being accumulated in memory.  I think this consistitutes a "memory leak", and becomes especially noticeable when the test classes have fields which hold a large amount of heap space.

Using "find nearest GC root" on any of the extra test instances, I see:

```
(my test instance)
testInstance, org.junit.jupiter.engine.descriptor.MethodExtensionContext
extensionContext, org.junit.jupiter.engine.execution.JupiterEngineExecutionContext$State
state org.junit.jupiter.engine.execution.JupiterEngineExecutionContext
context org.junit.platform.engine.support.hierarchical.NodeTestTask
...
elementData java.util.ArrayList (java frame)
```

Where the java frame is at:
```
org.junit.platform.engine.support.hierarchical.SameThreadHierarchicalTestExecutorService.invokeAll(SameThreadHierarchicalTestExecutorService.java:38)
```

By the way, the minimal testcase I provided here might be used as inspiration for a Junit 5 regression test, to guard the requirement that the memory held by a test class should not be multipled by the number of test methods in that class in order to set the max heap size requirement... that's too expensive and will certainly break lots of project's existing tests.

Looks like this issue was created by the changes to support parallel test execution.  I suspect there may be some passing around of lists where perhaps iterators/streams could be used to avoid holding everything in memory simulatenously?

Note that I'm not enabling parallel test execution.  I think it's totally reasonable to impose some memory usage increases upon parallel test execution (since of course it cannot be avoided).  But when running with the feature disabled, the mere existence of the feature shouldn't impose major memory usage increases.  Indeed, I think the memory usage implications of parallel test execution will be a significant consideration for users to consider before enabling it... some will choose to stick with something more like gradle's multi-JVM-process parallelism, while others will need Junit 5's version of parallelism.

Great detective work, @tcfurrer! :+1: Just to clarify, do the test class instances you see belong to the currently executed test or are the references retained even though the tests were already executed in the past. Being fastidious, I think only the latter would be a memory leak (or the Java variant thereof) that _must_ be fixed whereas the former _could_ be judged as a valid trade-off. (Although I agree that it's not nice to punish users for a feature that they don't use.)

Quick tip: To format code snippets, start and end them with three backticks on an otherwise empty line. To improve highlighting, you can even mention the language:

    ```java
    System.out.println("Java code snippet)";
    ```

Results in:

```java
System.out.println("Java code snippet)";
```
Thanks for the detailed analysis and the minimal show-case.
Marked as a "bug" for now, as it is a regression.

rename.to: OutOfMemoryError in test suite when upgrading from JUnit 5.2 to 5.3

body:
@tcfurrer, thank you for reporting the issue, the detailed analysis, and the sample to reproduce the bug.

Much appreciated!

I can confirm that this is a bug thanks to the example provided by @tcfurrer.

And as @sormuras mentioned elsewhere, switching to test instance per-class lifecycle avoids the issue, as expected.
